tutorial.title: Using OR
tutorial.descriptionContent: Using OR to chain condition options

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use OR to chain different filtering options, like selecting students who are majoring in Biology or are in their first year.

Click the buttons to see the difference between the filters.

lessons.title: The logical operator OR
lessons.interactiveContent:
Just like with AND, we use the logical operator OR to chain two or more conditions.

Make sure to type OR.

lessons.title: At least one condition
lessons.interactiveContent:
Unlike AND, using OR gives us items that satisfy at least one of the chained conditions.

Make sure to pick OR, followed by year = 1.

lessons.title: At least one condition 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
This is why we'll get items like Lin Wong, 3, Biology, which matches major = 'Biology', but doesn't match year = 1.

Make sure to type year = 1.

lessons.title: No duplicates
lessons.interactiveContent:
Using OR doesn't give duplicate results. Items that satisfy both conditions, like Ava Smith, 1, Biology get selected only once.

Make sure to pick = followed by 'Biology' and then =, 1.

lessons.title: Question: At least one condition
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this query select?

Items that satisfy at least one of the conditions linked with ORItems that satisfy all of the conditions linked with OR

Items that satisfy at least one of the conditions linked with OR.

lessons.title: Question: At least one condition 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens when an item satisfies only one of the conditions linked with OR?

The query selects it since items need to satisfy at least one conditionThe query doesn't select it since it doesn't meet all conditions

The query selects it since items need to satisfy at least one condition.

lessons.title: Question: No duplicates
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens when an item satisfies all conditions linked with OR?

The query selects it only onceThe query selects it multiple times, once for each satisfied condition

The query selects it only once.

lessons.title: Example: The logical operator OR
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select items manufactured by 'Ford' or made in 2019 by coding OR between the two conditions.

Make sure to type OR.

lessons.title: Example: At least one condition
lessons.interactiveContent:
Make sure the query also selects 2, Bentley, 2019 by coding OR followed by the condition year = 2019.

Make sure to type OR year = 2019.

lessons.title: Example: At least one condition 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Choose manufacturer and year values, so that the query selects the items 2, Bentley, 2019 and 3, Ford, 1970.

Make sure to pick 'Bentley', followed by 1970.

lessons.title: Any kind of conditions
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use OR to chain any kind of conditions, like selecting students majoring in 'Biology' or students in a year <= 2.

Make sure to type year <= 2.

lessons.title: Any kind of conditions 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
This gives us all students items with major = 'Biology' plus all students that are in their first and second years.

Make sure to pick major, followed by OR, and finally year.

lessons.title: IN, BETWEEN, or LIKE
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also use IN, BETWEEN, or LIKE. Here, we're selecting students majoring in 'Biology' or having a name starting with s.

Make sure to pick OR followed by name and then LIKE, 's%'.

lessons.title: As many as we want
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can chain as many conditions as we want. Add OR, followed by year = 1 as a third option.

Make sure to type OR year = 1.

lessons.title: Question: Any kind of conditions
lessons.interactiveContent:
What kind of conditions can we chain with OR?

Any kindOnly conditions using =

Any kind.

lessons.title: Question: Any kind of conditions 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this query select?

Items with an ID of 2, or year greater than 1970Items with both an ID of 2 and a year greater than1970

Items with an ID of 2, or year greater than 1970.

lessons.title: Question: IN, BETWEEN, or LIKE
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this query select?

Items with an ID between 1 and 3, or a manufacturer of either 'Jaguar' or 'Ford'Items with a manufacturer different from 'Jaguar' and'Ford'

Items with an ID between 1 and 3, or a manufacturer of either 'Jaguar' or 'Ford'.

lessons.title: Question: As many as we want
lessons.interactiveContent:
How many conditions can we chain with OR?

As many as we wantAt most two

As many as we want.

lessons.title: Example: Any kind of conditions
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select items with an ID of 2 or with a year greater than 1960.

Make sure to pick = followed by 2 and then OR, year > 1960.

lessons.title: Example: IN, BETWEEN, or LIKE
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select items with a year between 1950 and 1970 or a manufacturer starting with the letter j.

Make sure to pick WHERE followed by BETWEEN 1950 AND 1970 and then OR, manufacturer, LIKE 'j%'.

lessons.title: Example: As many as we want
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code OR, then add ID = 4 as a third condition.

Make sure to type OR ID = 4.

lessons.title: Same as IN
lessons.interactiveContent:
As a special case, a condition like major = 'History' OR major = 'Physics' is equivalent to major IN ('History', 'Physics').

Make sure to pick major = 'History', followed by OR, and finally 'Physics'.

lessons.title: Same as IN 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we replace the previous conditions with major IN ('History', 'Physics'), we get the same result table.

Make sure to pick IN followed by ( and then 'History', 'Physics', ).

lessons.title: When to replace
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can replace IN conditions with OR when each condition uses the = operator and restricts the same column, like major.

Make sure to pick major followed by = and then major, =.

lessons.title: Different columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can't use IN to replace a condition like major = 'History' OR name = 'Ava Smith', since it restricts two columns: major and name.

Make sure to type name.

lessons.title: Different operators
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can't replace with IN the condition major = 'History' OR major <> 'Physics', since both operators need to be =.

Make sure to pick major, followed by <>, and finally 'Physics'.

lessons.title: Question: Same as IN
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which conditions are equivalent to the one in the query?

manufacturer = 'Bentley' OR manufacturer = 'Jaguar'manufacturer = 'Bentley' AND manufacturer = 'Jaguar'

manufacturer = 'Bentley' OR manufacturer = 'Jaguar'.

lessons.title: Question: Same as IN 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which condition is equivalent to year = 1970 OR year = 1980?

year IN (1970, 1980)year BETWEEN 1970 AND 1980

year IN (1970, 1980).

lessons.title: Question: When to replace
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why is year >= 1950 OR year <= 1970 not equivalent to year IN (1950, 1970)?

Because the first condition checks year is within a range of years and the second checks it's one of the values providedBecause the IN is not a valid keyword

Because the first condition checks year is within a range of years and the second checks it's one of the values provided.

lessons.title: Question: Different columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why is year = 1950 OR ID = 3 not equivalent to year IN (1950, 3)?

Because year = 1950 OR ID = 3 sets conditions on two different columnsBecause we can't use IN with number values

Because year = 1950 OR ID = 3 sets conditions on two different columns.

lessons.title: Example: Same as IN
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a condition equivalent to ID = 1 OR ID = 3.

Make sure to pick ID IN (1, 3).
